column4: Well, now I need a bit of help. I'm trying to run Ubuntu on a Dell Latitude D505, and the wireless card refuses to connect to anything. o_o I've found some fixes for older Ubuntu versions, but 9.10 doesn't use GRUB. o_o;;
that should get you the config file you want
I know how to do things in GRUB2. Thanks though.
you can add the same code to the grub2 conf
Yes, But I'd have to do it every time I needed to update the Ubuntu kernel image.
only if you add it to /boot/grub/grub.cfg
adding it to /etc/default/grub applies it every kernel update/grub change
Hold on. I'm going to try.
add it to /etc/default/grub then run sudo update-grub and all, it will be added to /boot/grub/grub.cfg automatically from there out
Do I add it anywhere?
so... find GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT=,  then add acpi=noirq between the quotes
New question. How do I remove old kernel entries?
while leaving them installed?
Removing them would be best for what I want.
synaptic works, just uninstall them
Where would I find them in Synaptic?
I know that. I want to know where to find the kernel images in Synaptic.
Status on the bottom left, up top click Installed, search for linux
Okay, just one moment.
sort by installed version, tada
Always recommended to have a fallback kernel installed, so leave one older version
It's a flash drive install. I back it up constantly, so I'm going to remove all but the current. ^_^
